statements.name: PROC QLIM
statements.description: The QLIM (qualitative and limited dependent variable model) procedure analyzes univariate and multivariate limited dependent variable models where dependent variables take discrete values or dependent variables are observed only in a limited range of values. This procedure includes logit, probit, tobit, selection, and multivariate models. The multivariate model can contain discrete choice and limited endogenous variables as well as continuous endogenous variables. † The QLIM procedure supports the following models: † o linear regression model with heteroscedasticity o Box-Cox regression with heteroscedasticity o probit with heteroscedasticity o logit with heteroscedasticity o tobit (censored and truncated) with heteroscedasticity o bivariate probit o bivariate tobit o sample selection and switching regression models o multivariate limited dependent variables o stochastic frontier production and cost models

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: CORROUT
arguments.description: Writes the correlation matrix for the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set. This option is valid only if the OUTEST= option is specified.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the method to calculate the covariance matrix of parameter estimates.

arguments.name: OP
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: QML
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices (the quasi-maximum likelihood estimates).

arguments.name: COVOUT
arguments.description: Writes the covariance matrix for the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set. This option is valid only if the OUTEST= option is specified.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set. If the DATA= option is not specified, PROC QLIM uses the most recently created SAS data set.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Prints the initial parameter estimates, convergence criteria, and all constraints of the optimization. At each iteration, objective function value, step size, maximum gradient, and slope of search direction are printed as well.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization method. If this option is specified, it overwrites the TECH= option in NLOPTIONS statement.
arguments.help: METHOD=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-gradient optimization

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double dogleg optimization

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization combining a line-search algorithm with ridging

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization with ridging

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Performs a quasi-Newton optimization

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a trust region optimization

arguments.name: NDRAW=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of draws for Monte Carlo integration.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the normal printed output but does not suppress error listings. If NOPRINT option is set, then any other print option is turned off.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Writes the parameter estimates to an output data set.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Turns on all the printing-control options. The options set by PRINTALL are COVB and CORRB.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies a seed for pseudo-random number generation in Monte Carlo integration.

statements.name: BOUNDS
statements.description: The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. BOUNDS statement constraints refer to the parameters estimated by the QLIM procedure. Any number of BOUNDS statements can be specified. Each bound is composed of parameters and constants and inequality operators. Parameters associated with regressor variables are referred to by the names of the corresponding regressor variables: item operator item < operator item < operator item ...> > Each item is a constant, the name of a parameter, or a list of parameter names. Each operator is ’<’, ’>’, ’≤’, or ’≥’.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC QLIM to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used in the analysis. Classification variables can be either character or numeric.

statements.name: ENDOGENOUS
statements.description: The ENDOGENOUS statement specifies the type of dependent variables that appear on the left-hand side of the equation. Endogenous variables listed refer to the dependent variables that appear on the left-hand side of the equation. Currently, no right-hand side endogeneity is handled in PROC QLIM. All variables appearing on the right-hand side of the equation are treated as exogenous

arguments.name: CENSORED=
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variables in this statement be censored. Valid censored-options are as follows: LB=value or variable LOWERBOUND=value or variable specifies the lower bound of the censored variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: DISCRETE=
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variables in this statement are discrete. Valid discrete-options are as follows: ORDER=DATA | FORMATTED | FREQ | INTERNAL specifies the sorting order for the levels of the discrete variables specified in the ENDOGENOUS statement. DISTRIBUTION=NORMAL|LOGISTIC DIST=NORMAL|LOGISTIC D=NORMAL|LOGISTIC specifies the cumulative distribution function used to model the response probabilities. Valid values are as follows: NORMAL the normal distribution for the probit model

arguments.name: FRONTIER=
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variable in this statement follow a production or cost frontier. Valid frontier-options are as follows: TYPE=HALF | EXPONENTIAL | TRUNCATED HALF specifies half-normal model. EXPONENTIAL specifies exponential model. TRUNCATED specifies truncated normal model. PRODUCTION specifies that the model estimated be a production function.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Specifies selection criteria for sample selection model. Select-option specifies the condition for the endogenous variable to be selected. It is written as a variable name, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, ≤, ≥), followed by a number: variable operator number The variable is the endogenous variable that the selection is based on. The operator can be =, <, >, ≤ , or ≥. Multiple select-options can be combined with the logic operators: AND, OR. The following example illustrates the use of the SELECT option:

arguments.name: TRUNCATED=
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variables in this statement be truncated. Valid truncated-options are as follows: LB=value or variable LOWERBOUND=value or variable specifies the lower bound of the truncated variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement identifies a variable that contains the frequency of occurrence of each observation. PROC QLIM treats each observation as if it appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. If it is not an integer, the frequency value is truncated to an integer. If the frequency value is less than 1 or missing, the observation is not used in the model fitting. When the FREQ statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a frequency of 1. If you specify more than one FREQ statement, then the first FREQ statement is used.

statements.name: HETERO
statements.description: The HETERO statement specifies variables that are related to the heteroscedasticity of the residuals and the way these variables are used to model the error variance.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: The functional form can be specified using the LINK= option.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Specifies a exponential link function.

arguments.name: LINEAR
arguments.description: Specifies a linear link function.

arguments.name: NOCONST
arguments.description: Specifies that there be no constant in the linear or exponential heteroscedasticity model.

arguments.name: SQUARE
arguments.description: Estimates the model by using the square of linear heteroscedasticity function.

statements.name: INIT
statements.description: The INIT statement is used to set initial values for parameters in the optimization. Any number of INIT statements can be specified. Each initvalue is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional equality operator (=), followed by a number: parameter <=> number

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the dependent variable and independent regressor variables for the regression model.

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Specifies options that are used for Box-Cox regression or regressor transformation. For example, the Box-Cox regression is specified as: model y = x1 x2 / boxcox(y=lambda,x1 x2)

arguments.name: LIMIT1=
arguments.description: Specifies the restriction of the threshold value of the first category when the ordinal probit or logit model is estimated. LIMIT1=ZERO is the default option. When LIMIT1=VARYING is specified, the threshold value is estimated.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

statements.name: NLOPTIONS
statements.description: PROC QLIM uses the be nonlinear optimization (NLO) subsystem to perform nonlinear optimization tasks.

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value of r is the negative square root of the largest double-precision value, which serves only as a protection against overflows.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value is r=0. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-5. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. The default is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: DAMPSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step length value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, HYQUAN, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step length value used in the former iteration. If the DAMPSTEP option is specified but r is not specified, the default is r=2. The DAMPSTEP=r option can prevent the line-search algorithm from repeatedly stepping into regions where some objective functions are difficult to compute or where they could lead to floating point overflows during the computation of objective functions and their derivatives. The DAMPSTEP=r option can save time-costly function calls during the line searches of objective functions that result in very small steps.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-8. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN=
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: o For TECH= TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: i=50 o For TECH= QUANEW, DBLDOG: i=200 o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400 o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=1000 These default values are also valid when i is specified as a missing value.

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer. Note that the time specified by the MAXTIME= option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than that specified by the MAXTIME= option. The actual running time includes the rest of the time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0. If you request more iterations than are actually needed for convergence to a stationary point, the optimization algorithms can behave strangely. For example, the effect of rounding errors can prevent the algorithm from continuing for the required number of iterations.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the output.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays all optional output for optimization.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history.

arguments.name: PHISTPARMS
arguments.description: Display parameter estimates in each iteration.

arguments.name: PINIT
arguments.description: Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).

arguments.name: PSHORT
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default output.

arguments.name: PSUMMARY
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and notes, warnings, and errors.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after, at most, i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. For all techniques except NMSIMP, termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations. The default value is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set containing all variables in the input data set and, optionally, the estimates of x'β, predicted value, residual, marginal effects, probability, standard deviation of the error, expected value, conditional expected value, and inverse Mills ratio. When the response values are missing for the observation, all output estimates except residual are still computed as long as none of the explanatory variables is missing. This enables you to compute these statistics for prediction. You can specify only one OUTPUT statement.

arguments.name: CONDITIONAL
arguments.description: Output estimates of conditional expected values of continuous endogenous

arguments.name: ERRSTD
arguments.description: Output estimates of σ-j, the standard deviation of the error term.

arguments.name: EXPECTED
arguments.description: Output estimates of expected values of continuous endogenous variables.

arguments.name: MARGINAL
arguments.description: Output marginal effects.

arguments.name: MILLS
arguments.description: Output estimates of inverse Mills ratios of censored or truncated continuous, binary discrete, and selection endogenous variables.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PREDICTED
arguments.description: Output estimates of predicted endogenous variables.

arguments.name: PROB
arguments.description: Output estimates of probability of discrete endogenous variables taking the current observed responses.

arguments.name: PROBALL
arguments.description: Output estimates of probability of discrete endogenous variables for all possible responses.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Output estimates of residuals of continuous endogenous variables.

arguments.name: TE1
arguments.description: Outputs estimates of technical efficiency for each producer in the stochastic frontier model suggested by Battese and Coelli (1988).

arguments.name: TE2
arguments.description: Outputs estimates of technical efficiency for each producer in the stochastic frontier model suggested by Jondrow et al. (1982).

arguments.name: XBETA
arguments.description: Output estimates of x'β.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement is used to impose linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. Any number of RESTRICT statements can be specified, but the number of restrictions imposed is limited by the number of regressors. Each restriction is written as an expression, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, ≤, ≥), followed by a second expression: expression operator expression The operator can be =, <, >, ≤ , or ≥. The operator and second expression are optional.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the regression parameters in the preceding MODEL statement. Each equation specifies a linear hypothesis to be tested. All hypotheses in one TEST statement are tested jointly. Variable names in the equations must correspond to regressors in the preceding MODEL statement, and each name represents the coefficient of the corresponding regressor. The keyword INTERCEPT refers to the coefficient of the intercept.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies a variable to supply weighting values to use for each observation in estimating parameters. The log likelihood for each observation is multiplied by the corresponding weight variable value. If the weight of an observation is nonpositive, that observation is not used in the estimation.
